title: Catherine Christer Hennix
text:
Catherine Christer Hennix (also known as C.C. Hennix, born 1948) is a Swedish musician, poet, philosopher, mathematician and visual artist. As a musician, she has worked with figures such as <a href="Pandit%20Pran%20Nath">Pandit Pran Nath</a>, <a href="La%20Monte%20Young">La Monte Young</a>, and <a href="Henry%20Flynt">Henry Flynt</a>. Several of her archival recordings have been released in the 21st century, most prominently "The Electric Harpsichord" (2010). Hennix was affiliated with <a href="MIT">MIT</a>'s <a href="AI%20Lab">AI Lab</a> in the late 1970s and was later employed as research professor of mathematics at <a href="SUNY%20New%20Paltz">SUNY New Paltz</a>; she also worked with mathematician <a href="Alexander%20Esenin-Volpin">Alexander Esenin-Volpin</a>.
Biography.
Catherine Christer Hennix grew up in a musical environment; her mother was a <a href="jazz">jazz</a> composer who frequently invited well-known American jazz musicians such as <a href="Idrees%20Sulieman">Idrees Sulieman</a> and <a href="Eric%20Dolphy">Eric Dolphy</a> around the house, and she saw <a href="John%20Coltrane">John Coltrane</a> and others perform. Hennix took up drums and performed with her brother. Later, Hennix studied with <a href="Stockhausen">Stockhausen</a> and was among the pioneers in Sweden experimenting with main-frame computer generated composite sound wave forms in the late 1960s. She studied <a href="bio-chemistry">bio-chemistry</a> and then <a href="linguistics">linguistics</a> at university before settling on <a href="mathematical%20logic">mathematical logic</a> and <a href="philosophy">philosophy</a>. 
In the 1970s, she connected with <a href="Fluxus">Fluxus</a> artists <a href="Dick%20Higgins">Dick Higgins</a> and <a href="Allison%20Knowles">Allison Knowles</a> in New York, and began collaborative relationships with figures such as <a href="La%20Monte%20Young">La Monte Young</a> and <a href="Henry%20Flynt">Henry Flynt</a>. She pursued studies with <a href="raga">raga</a> master <a href="Pandit%20Pran%20Nath">Pandit Pran Nath</a> and led the <a href="just%20intonation">just intonation</a> live-electronic ensembles Hilbert Hotel and The Deontic Miracle. At the urging of Nath, she also pursued a career as a professor of mathematics and computer science, and assistant to and coauthor with <a href="Alexander%20Esenin-Volpin">Alexander Esenin-Volpin</a> for which she was given the Centenary Prize Fellow Award by the <a href="Clay%20Mathematics%20Institute">Clay Mathematics Institute</a> in 2000. She was affiliated with <a href="MIT">MIT</a>'s <a href="AI%20Lab">AI Lab</a> in the late 1970s and was later employed as research professor of mathematics at <a href="SUNY%20New%20Paltz">SUNY New Paltz</a>. In the 1990s, she relocated to Paris to study <a href="psychoanalysis">psychoanalysis</a> with students of <a href="Jacques%20Lacan">Jacques Lacan</a>.
Hennix's interest in <a href="drone%20music">drone music</a> is crossed with her interests in jazz, <a href="Arabic">Arabic</a> music, <a href="Sufi">Sufi Islamic</a> art, and <a href="blues">blues</a> elements. In the 1970s and 1980s, she played with musicians such as <a href="Arthur%20Russell%20%28musician%29">Arthur Russell</a> and <a href="Arthur%20Rhames">Arthur Rhames</a>. She also performed in Flynt's group Dharma Warriors. Archival recordings such as "The Electric Harpsichord" (2010) and "Selected Early Keyboard Works" (2018) saw release in the 21st century. In recent years, she has performed with her group the Chora(s)san Time-Court Mirage. In 2019, many of her writings were published in the two-volume collection "Poësy Matters and Other Matters".
Discography.
Releases credited to Hennix and her various groups.
